choices.D: When guided by an authorized sales engineer, it helps determine the areas of greatest risk where you should focus prevention activities
choices.C: It shows how your current configuration compares to Palo Alto Networks recommendations
choices.B: It provides a set of questionnaires that help uncover security risk prevention gaps across all areas of network and security architecture

discussion.content:
Option C

The Best Practice Assessment (BPA) tool compares the configuration of firewalls and Panorama to the Palo Alto Networks best practice recommendations. Run the BPA periodically to identify security weaknesses, see the best practice settings, and implement them to improve your security posture.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/best-practices/10-2/bpa-getting-started

Selected Answer: C
C
for sure!

Selected Answer: C
https://www.paloaltonetworks.jp/services/bpa
C is correct

questions.question_text: Which statement is true regarding a Best Practice Assessment?

discussion.content: Common sense in the real world, c would be pretty important. Connection throughput. But I guess this is not the real world

Selected Answer: ABE
Step one of the Plan your SD-WAN config is, "Plan the branch and hub locations, link requirements, and IP addresses. From Panorama you will export an empty SD-WAN device CSV and populate it with branch and hub information."

Plan the branch and hub locations, link requirements, and IP addresses. From Panorama you will export an empty SD-WAN device CSV and populate it with branch and hub information.

There is no way that Connection Throuput is not considered during SDWAN planning. I did many of these and C is one of the most important if not the most.

ABE : Plan the branch and hub locations, link requirements, and IP addresses.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/sd-wan/3-0/sd-wan-admin/sd-wan-overview/plan-sd-wan-configuration

questions.question_text: A standalone firewall with local objects and policies needs to be migrated into Panorama. What procedure should you use so Panorama is fully managing the firewall?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct 
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClZSCA0

Selected Answer: A
A. See link posted below.

Selected Answer: A
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClZSCA0

choices.C: Use the "import Panorama configuration snapshot" operation, then "export or push device config bundle" to push the configuration
choices.D: Use the "import device configuration to Panorama" operation, then perform a device-group commit push with "include device and network templates"
choices.A: Use the "import device configuration to Panorama" operation, then "export or push device config bundle" to push the configuration
choices.B: Use the "import Panorama configuration snapshot" operation, then perform a device-group commit push with "include device and network templates"

discussion.content:
A, C & D are correct, checked on my lab running 10.1
There is also (not listed on the question) pre log on always on

Selected Answer: ACD
I can't believe we should memorize this. There are 5 options under GP; 6 options under Portal; 6 options under Agent Config; and more than 50 options under App! easy to answer looking at my FW configuration.

Selected Answer: ACD
A C D are correct

On-demand (Manual user initiated connection)
User-logon (Always On)
Pre-logon (Always On)
Pre-logon then On-demand

Selected Answer: ACD
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-web-interface-help/globalprotect/network-globalprotect-portals/globalprotect-portals-agent-configuration-tab/globalprotect-portals-agent-app-tab

questions.question_text: When you navigate to Network > GlobalProtect > Portals > Agent > (config) > App and look in the Connect Method section, which three options are available? (Choose three.)

choices.C: You cannot find failover details on closed sessions

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I believe the answer here is D. Traffic logs. Refer to the documentation link below, you can see that the link switches, and all SD-WAN cluster logs are found in the firewalls traffic logs. https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/monitoring/use-syslog-for-monitoring/syslog-field-descriptions/traffic-log-fields#idbe18d2d4-9eb8-4966-bec8-df3a6de70e66

Selected Answer: D
The system logs contains link failover details

Selected Answer: A
The question is regarding the "reason" which correlates with the sd-wan event logs writen into the system logs.

Selected Answer: A
same with Chiquitabandita

Selected Answer: A
System logs display entries for each system event on the firewall. Each entry includes the date and time, event severity, and event description. The following table summarizes the System log severity levels. For a partial list of System log messages and their corresponding severity levels, refer to System Log Events.
SEVERITY
DESCRIPTION
Critical
Hardware failures, including high availability (HA) failover and link failures.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/monitoring/view-and-manage-logs/log-types-and-severity-levels/system-logs#id8edbfdae-ed92-4d8e-ab76-6a38f96e8cb1

Selected Answer: D
Link Switches (link_switches): Contains up to four link flap entries, with each entry containing the link name, link tag, link type, physical interface, timestamp, bytes read, bytes written, link health, and link flap cause.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/monitoring/use-syslog-for-monitoring/syslog-field-descriptions/traffic-log-fields#idbe18d2d4-9eb8-4966-bec8-df3a6de70e66:~:text=link%20health%2C%20and-,link%20flap%20cause.,-SD%2DWAN%20Cluster
System logs contain sub type routing.. basically shows failover logs.. could be A

Selected Answer: C
They have it correct at C. The system logs will not tell you "the reason for a session failover" which is what the question asks.
They have it correct at C. The system logs will not tell you "the reason for a session failover" which is what the question asks.

Selected Answer: A
Why not A? How can you find the "reason" for a failover in the traffic logs?

Selected Answer: D
D is the answer

Selected Answer: D
D is the answer I think, sessions may failover on different paths based on the traffic distribution profiles: https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/sd-wan/1-0/sd-wan-admin/configure-sd-wan/sd-wan-traffic-distribution-profiles
I also think D. Traffic logs are for closed sessions, session browser for open.

C cannot be correct. I do not see the correct answer in here, but not sure if the traffic logs can reveal this information. According to documentation, the failover reason can be found in (Panorama - SD-WAN - Monitoring). Here's the link - check out step 6 - https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/sd-wan/1-0/sd-wan-admin/troubleshooting/troubleshoot-app-performance

questions.question_text:
An administrator has configured PAN-OS SD-WAN and has received a request to find out the reason for a session failover for a session that has already ended.
Where would you find this in Panorama or firewall logs?
